newsitem.title: INDIA: Profit-taking wipes sharp gains in India shares.
newsitem.headline: Profit-taking wipes sharp gains in India shares.

text.p: ** Indian shares end higher, but off sharp
mid-session rally as operators book profits
** Bombay's benchmark 30-share index up 28.36 pts, 0.75
pct to 3,828.99, below 3,864.77 --day's high
** Reliance most actively traded stock at Bombay
exchanges, up two pct on National Stock Exchange
due to no-delivery period in new account
** Foreign funds active bidders in select stocks
** National exchange index up over one pct at 1,071.05
** Calcutta share index gains 0.17 pts to 106.32, Madras
index down 72.82 pts at 3,630.08
Bombay shares ended with small gains on Wednesday, capping a smart mid-session rally after a round of late profit-taking, traders said.
"The market has shown a minor reaction," said Antony Sequeira, managing director at Arcadia Share & Stock Brokers.
Fresh buying by foreign investors coupled with support from some local funds helped blue chips such as Mahindra & Mahindra, Colgate, MTNL and TELCO close higher, traders said.
New prime minister Inder Kumar Gujral on Tuesday won a parliamentary vote of confidence, ending a three-week political drama that brought India to the brink of a mid-term election.
"Political stability seems to be there now," Arcadia's Sequiera said.
The rally in share prices, however, took traders by surprise in the absence of a single major factor triggering the rise.
"The market should be steady and rise slowly," said Mahendra Doshi, director at LKP Shares & Securities. "Speculators tried to cover short-positions and that pushed up prices."
Market leader Reliance Industries added nearly two percent to 306.80 rupees at the National Stock Exchange (NSE) after the stock entered a no-delivery account from Wednesday.
A no-delivery period allows speculators to trade the stock without actual purchase or delivery for one month.
At the Bombay Stock Exchange, Reliance shares fell 1.75 rupees to 306.25, with over 6.81 million shares traded.
The petrochemicals giant on Tuesday said its 1996/97 net climbed to 13.23 billion rupees from 13.05 billion a year ago.
Steel Authority of India Ltd (SAIL) fell after the Steel Ministry forecast a lower net profit for the company in 1996/97. The stock ended 1.75 rupees below the day's high of 24.25.
SAIL's net profit in 1996/97 (April-March) was estimated at 6.53 billion rupees, down from 13.19 billion a year ago.
-- Anshuman Daga, Bombay equities desk +91-22-265 9000
